block.p: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
MUSIC
APPEL FARM ARTS AND MUSIC CENTER Grey Eye Glances. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $22. 457 Shirley Road, Elmer. (800) 394-1211.

An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
MUSIC
APPEL FARM ARTS AND MUSIC CENTER Grey Eye Glances. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $22. 457 Shirley Road, Elmer. (800) 394-1211.

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN MIDDLE SCHOOL Art Center Chamber Music Concert Series, featuring the Emerson String Quartet. Tuesday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $60 (full series of four concerts); limited individual seats available. 335 DeMott Avenue, Teaneck (201) 836-3547.

BERGEN COUNTY TECHNICAL HIGH SCHOOL ''An Evening of American Acoustic Music,'' featuring David Bromberg, Jay Ungar, Molly Mason, Danny O'Keefe and Peter Ecklund. Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 and $35. Auditorium, 200 Hackensack Avenue, Hackensack. (201) 507-8900.

CHRIST CHURCH Lunchtime Recital Series, featuring Ocean Winds Trio (flute, clarinet and oboe). Wednesday, 12:15 p.m. to 12:45 p.m. Free; reception to follow. 5 Paterson Street, New Brunswick. (732) 545-6262.

COMMUNITY THEATER OF MORRISTOWN Colonial Symphony's 50th Season Opening Concert titled ''Heartstrings.'' Saturday at 8:30 p.m.; Pre-concert lecture at 7:30 p.m. with Martin Bookspan. Tickets: $36, $27 and $14; $5 for students. 100 South Street, Morristown. (973) 539-8008.

JOHN HARMS CENTER FOR THE ARTS Herbie Hancock and Wayne Shorter. Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $40. Opening Night Gala, starring Ray Charles, with Andy Bey, vocalist/pianist. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $30 to $65. 30 North Van Brunt Street, Englewood. (201) 567-3600.
McCARTER THEATER John Hiatt, acoustic singer and songwriter. Tuesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $27 to $32. 91 University Place, Princeton. (609) 258-2787.

MORRISTOWN UNITARIAN FELLOWSHIP Fellowship's 20th Saturday Evening Concert Series, featuring Wu Han, pianist, and David Finckel, cellist. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25. 21 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 627-3282.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER India Bamboleo. Today at 5 p.m. Tickets: $13 to $45. Prudential Hall. Tito Paris. Saturday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $25. Victoria Theater. NDR Symphony Orchestra of Hamburg, Christoph Eschenbach, conductor, Midori, violinist. Next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $12 to $49. Prudential Hall. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.
PRINCETON UNIVERSITY RICHARDSON AUDITORIUM The Takacs String Quartet. Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $29, $24 and $19; $2 for students. Alexander Hall, Princeton. (609) 258-5000.
PRINCETON UNIVERSITY TAPLIN AUDITORIUM The Composers' Ensemble at Princeton. Tuesday at 8 p.m. Free. Taplin Auditorium, Fine Hall. Washington Road, Princeton. (609) 258-4239.
PUFFIN CULTURAL FORUM ''Jam Sessions at the Puffin,'' featuring Calvin Hill and his trio. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $5. 20 East Oakdene Avenue, Teaneck. (201) 836-8923.

ROWAN UNIVERSITY Duo Capriccioso. Today at 7 p.m. Tickets: $13. Regina Carter. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $13, $16 and $19. Pfleeger Concert Hall, Wilson Hall, Glassboro Center for the Arts, Route 322, Glassboro. (856) 256-4545.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - CAMDEN Keiko Sato, pianist. Wednesday at noon. Free. Mallery Room, Second Floor, Fine Arts Complex, Third Street between Cooper Street and the Benjamin Franklin Bridge, Camden. (856) 225-6176.
ST. FRANCIS DE SALES CHURCH The Chamber Music at Great Gorge Foundation. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $12; $9 for students and older people; $5 for children under 12. Route 517, Vernon. (973) 927-4203.

ST. PETER'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH Carillon Concert, featuring John Widman, guest carillonneur. Today at 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $8; $5 for students and older people. 70 Maple Avenue, Morristown. (973) 538-0555.

SOMERSET COUNTY VOCATIONAL AND TECHNICAL SCHOOL ''Jazz in Bridgewater'' series, featuring ''Piano Greats,'' celebrating their new Altenburg Grand, with Derek Smith and John Bunch. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15. Auditorium, Vogt Drive, near North Bridge Street, Bridgewater. (908) 526-8900, ext. 7219.

SOUTH ORANGE MIDDLE SCHOOL ''Giants of Jazz III'' concert, paying tribute to Jimmy Heath, tenor sax player. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $30 (advance); $35 (at the door). Sterling Hall Auditorium, 70 North Ridgewood Road, South Orange. (973) 378-7754, extension 1 or (201) 507-8900.

STATE THEATER ''Family Concerts: Music for Young People,'' featuring the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, Mark Laycock, conductor. Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $11 and $16. 15 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-7469.

STOCKTON PERFORMING ARTS CENTER ''Keyboard Conversations,'' featuring Jeffrey Siegel, pianist. Today at 4 p.m. Ottmar Liebert and Luna Negra. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 (orchestra); $20 (mezzanine). The Richard Stockton College of New Jersey, Jim Leeds Road, Pomona. (609) 652-9000.

UNITARIAN CHURCH OF PRINCETON Le Triomphe de l'amour, New Jersey's chamber ensemble. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $14; $10 for older people; $3 for students. Intersection of Route 206 and Cherry Valley Road, Princeton. (609) 730-8796.
UNITY CONCERTS OF NEW JERSEY The American String Quartet. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $30. Mount Hebron Auditorium, Montclair. (973) 744-6770.
WATCHUNG ARTS CENTER Harmonytryx, all-female a cappella ensemble. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $10. Watchung Circle, 18 Stirling Road, Watchung. (908) 753-0190.

WESTMINSTER CHOIR COLLEGE OF RIDER UNIVERSITY Faculty Recital, featuring Margaret Cusack, soprano, and J. J. Penna, pianist. Today at 4 p.m. Faculty Recital, featuring Stefan Engels, organist. Friday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $10; $8 for students and older people. Conservatory Family Concert: 1864 Union League Rally. Saturday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $5. Bristol Chapel, 101 Walnut Lane, Princeton. (609) 921-2663, ext. 308.

WILLIAM PATERSON UNIVERSITY 2000 Midday Artists' Series, featuring Seth Himmelhoch, classical guitarist. Thursday at 12:30 p.m. Tickets: $3. Fall 2000 Jazz Room Series: Mulgrew Mill and Wingspan. Today at 4 p.m. Tickets: $12, $9 for William Paterson community. Shea Center for Performing Arts, 300 Pompton Road, Wayne. (973) 720-2371.
THEATER

AMERICAN STAGE COMPANY ''Forever Plaid.'' Through Oct. 22. Performances are Thursdays at 7:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 7 p.m. and Wednesday and Sunday matinees at 2:30 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $30. Becton Hall, Fairleigh Dickinson University, 1000 River Road, Teaneck. (201) 692-7744.

CENTENARY PERFORMING ARTS ''Blithe Spirit.'' Friday through Oct. 28. Performances are Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays and Wednesdays at 2:30 p.m.; and Thursdays at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $15; $12.50 for children under 12. 400 Jefferson Street, Hackettstown. (908) 979-0900.
COMMUNITY THEATER OF MORRISTOWN Paula Poundstone. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $35. 100 South Street, Morristown. (973) 539-8008.

GEORGE STREET PLAYHOUSE ''Wit,'' by Margaret Edson. Previews begin Saturday at 8 p.m.; runs Oct. 18 through Nov. 12. Performances are Tuesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. Tickets: $24 to $40. 9 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-7717.

KELSEY THEATER ''Arsenic and Old Lace.'' Today at 3 p.m. ''Little Shop of Horrors.'' Fridays and Saturdays through Oct. 21 at 8 p.m.; next Sunday and Oct. 22 at 3 p.m.; Oct. 21 at 1 p.m. Tickets: $12; $10 for students, children and older people. Mercer County Community College, 1200 Trenton Road, Trenton. (609) 584-9444.

LUMIA THEATER The New Jersey Repertory Company presents ''In Search of Red River Dog.'' Thursday through Nov. 5. Performances at Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sunday matinees at 2 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $27. 179 Broadway, Long Branch. (732) 229-3166.
McCARTER THEATER Bale Folclorico da Bahia: Carnival 2000. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $27 and $30. Center for the Performing Arts, 91 University Place, Princeton. (609) 258-2787.
MONTCLAIR STATE UNIVERSITY The Aquila Theater Company presents ''Cyrano de Bergerac.'' Saturday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $20. Valley Road and Normal Avenue, Upper Montclair. (973) 655-5112.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER ''Speaking in Tongues: Theater of the Spoken Word,'' featuring Taalam Acey, Sarah Jones, Will Power, Faraji Salim and others. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $10. The Chase Room. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.

PARK THEATER ''Cuba Operator Please,'' presented by the Hudson Exploited Theater Company and the Park Performing Arts Center. Friday and Oct. 20 at 8 p.m.; Oct. 22 at 3 p.m. Tickets: $10 and $15. 560 32nd Street, Union City. (201) 865-6980, extension 20.

PARSIPPANY PLAYHOUSE ''Mack and Mabel.'' Through Oct. 21. Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $22; $17 for students; $15 for older people. 1130 Knoll Road, Parsippany. (973) 263-7020.

WILLIAM PATERSON UNIVERSITY ''A Couple of Blaguards'' by Frank and Malachy McCourt, a national tour presented by Mainstage Productions. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $22; $20 for older people; $12 for students. Shea Center For Performing Arts, 300 Pompton Road, Wayne. (973) 720-2371.

PREMIER THEATER COMPANY ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat.'' Friday through Oct. 28. Performances at Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $20; $18 for older people; $15 for students; $12 for children. Algonquin Arts Theater, 169 Main Street, Manasquan. (732) 223-7122.

ROWAN UNIVERSITY ''Blood Wedding.'' Friday through Oct. 21. Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 3 p.m.; Oct. 19 at 6 p.m. Tickets: $7; $3 for students, alumni and older people. Tohill Theater, Bunce Hall, Glassboro. (856) 256-4545.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - NEW BRUNSWICK Rutgers Theater Company presents ''In the Boom Boom Room,'' by David Rabe. Tuesday through Oct. 22. Performances are Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $19; $17 for older people; $9 for students. Philip J. Levin Theater, Douglass Campus, New Brunswick. (732) 932-7511.

STATE THEATER ''Seven at the State,'' featuring the American Repertory Ballet and the Princeton Symphony Orchestra, presenting ''New Work by Kirk Peterson'' world premiere; ''Paramour'' company premiere; and ''Angels in the Architecture'' company premier. Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $45. 15 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-7469.

WOMEN'S THEATER COMPANY ''Myrtie,'' by Deborah Smith. Through Oct. 21. Performances are Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15; $12 for students and older people. 33 Green Village Road, Madison. (973) 443-9125.
MUSEUMS AND GALLERIES

ABC GALLERY ''Organic Movement'' of works by Monica McNulty. Thursday through Nov. 16. Opening reception: Thursday, 6 p.m. to 8 p.m. Hours: Mondays and Thursdays, 1 to 9 p.m.; Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 p.m. to 5 p.m. ; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Lambertville Public Library, 6 Lilly Street, Lambertville. (609) 397-0275.

AMERICAN LABOR MUSEUM ''Workers' Portraits,'' photodocumentary exhibit by Robert Gumpert. Through Dec. 31. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; other times by appointment. Botto House National Landmark, 83 Norwood Street, Haledon. (973) 595-7953.

ATRIUM GALLERY ''Fanciful Visions,'' exhibition featuring a collection of paintings by Andrea Baruffi. Through Oct. 31. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Chubb, 15 Mountain View Road, Warren. (908) 903-2608.

BERLEX LABORATORIES CORPORATE HEADQUARTERS ''Parallel Visions: A Compilation of G. J. Cloninger and Company Gallery Artists.'' Through Nov. 15. By appointment. 340 Changebridge Road, Montville. (973) 276-2000.

CHAMOT GALLERY ''Paint and Clay,'' paintings by Richard Estell and sculptures by Bruce Morozko. Through Nov. 12. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. 111 First Street, Jersey City. (201) 610-1468.

EXTENSION GALLERY ''Animal, Mineral and Vegetable'' exhibition of sculptures and photographs by Rory Mahon. Tomorrow through Nov. 9. Opening reception: Saturday, 4 p.m. to 7 p.m. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; other times by appointment. 60 Ward Avenue Extension, Mercerville. (609) 890-7777.

FAIRLEIGH DICKINSON UNIVERSITY ''A Florham Sketchbook,'' exhibit of pen and ink drawings by Floyd R. Gellerman. Through Oct. 20. Hours: Sundays, 2 to 10 p.m.; Mondays through Thursdays, 8:30 a.m. to 11 p.m.; Fridays, 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. The library, 285 Madison Avenue, Madison. (973) 443-8515.

GROUNDS FOR SCULPTURE ''James Dinerstein: New Sculpture,'' works in cast bronze. Through April 8, 2001. Hours: Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Tuesday and Wednesday by appointment. 18 Fairgrounds Road, Hamilton Township. (609) 586-0616.

HUNTERDON MUSEUM OF ART ''Runway: Photographs by Larry Fink,'' an exhibit of behind-the-scenes photos from the world of fashion and haute couture. Through Nov. 26. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 7 Lower Center Street, Clinton. (908) 735-8415.

J.C.C. ON THE PALISADES ''Beijing Through the Mist of Time.'' Through Oct. 29. Hours: Monday through Thursday, 9 a.m to 10 p.m.; Friday and Sunday, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Waltuch Gallery, 411 East Clinton Avenue, Tenafly. (201) 569-7900, extension 433.

KEAN UNIVERSITY ''Design at the Millennium: The 100 Greatest Designs of the Past Thousand Years.'' Through Oct. 28. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 3 p.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 5 p.m. Downs Hall, South Campus, Morris and North Avenues, near Elizabeth. (908) 527-3059.

MACCULLOCH HALL HISTORICAL MUSEUM ''Lasting Impressions,'' an exhibit on the history and techniques of printmaking. Through Jan. 14, 2001. Admission: $4; $3 for older people and students. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. 45 Macculloch Avenue, Morristown. (973) 538-2404.

MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM ''Lyrical Visions: Music and Dance in American and Native American Art.'' ''Georgia O'Keeffe: The Artist's Landscape, Photographs by Todd Webb.'' Through Jan. 7, 2001. ''Croquet: The Art of Play.' Through next Sunday (course will be open Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.) Admission: $7; $4 for children. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $4 for older people and students; free for members and children under 12. 3 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair. (973) 746-5555.

MONTCLAIR STATE UNIVERSITY ''Survey of Contemporary African Art,'' more than 50 works by artists from Algeria, Ghana, Mali, Nigeria and Senegal. Through Oct. 20. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. University Gallery, Life Hall, Valley Road and Normal Avenue, Upper Montclair. (973) 655-7640.

MORRIS COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''Women's Work is Never Done,'' an exhibition on the history and impact of the women's suffrage movement in New Jersey. Through Jan. 28, 2001. Hours: Mondays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students. Acorn Hall, 68 Morris Avenue, Morristown. (973) 267-3465.

MORRIS MUSEUM New Jersey Arts Annual: ''Everything for the Home'' juried exhibition. Through Nov. 17. ''Art and Nature: The Hudson River School'' exhibition. Through Nov. 19. Hours: Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for older people and children under age 3. 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 538-0454.

NEW JERSEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''Resource-Full New Jersey,'' an exhibition on natural resources, past and present, and land-use consequences. Through 2002. ''Dining In, Dining Out,'' featuring photographs, video clips, rare silverware, period furniture and 18th-century cookbooks. Through summer 2001. ''Pride of Newark: Baseball's Bears and Eagles,'' about the history of baseball in Newark. Through March 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 52 Park Place, Newark. (973) 596-8500.

NEW JERSEY STATE MUSEUM ''Leonard Baskin, Clarence Carter, Jacob Lawrence and George Segal: New Jersey Remembers.'' Through Oct. 22. ''Woven by Tradition and Design: A Selection of American Indian Weavings, Textiles and Baskets.'' Through Dec. 31. ''Click! The Marvelous in American Vernacular Photography.'' Through Dec. 31. ''Dinosaurs, Ammonites and Asteroids.'' Through Jan. 21, 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 4:45 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Free. 205 West State Street, Trenton. (609) 292-6464.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Night Skies: The Art of Deep Space,'' astral photographs by David Malin. Wednesday through Feb. 25, 2001. ''Katherine Choy: A Promise Unfulfilled'' ceramic showcase. Through Jan. 21, 2001. ''Treasures of 19th-Century American Art.'' Through Dec. 3. ''Year of the Dragon: The Calligraphy of Wang Fangyu.'' Through Nov. 12. ''Needless Necessity: Jewelry, Silver and Personal Meaning.'' Through December. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Thursdays (after hours) until 8:30 p.m. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6550.

NOYES MUSEUM OF ART ''Art in Boxes: Hers and His Stories.'' Through Jan. 7, 2001. ''Fred Returns: Selected Works of Fred Noyes From the Permanent Collection.'' Through Feb. 4, 20001. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: $3; $2 for older people and students. Lily Lake Road, Oceanville. (609) 652-8848.

PRINCETON UNIVERSITY ART MUSEUM ''What Photographs Look Like.'' Through Oct. 15. ''Dutch Prints in the Golden Age.'' Through Nov. 5. ''Life in the Fin de Siecle: Lithographs of Toulouse-Lautrec.'' Through Oct. 29. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Princeton campus. (609) 258-3788.

PUFFIN CULTURAL FORUM ''Sex, Lies and Politics: Cartoonists Shooting From the Hip,'' current and historic political cartoons. Through Oct. 29. Hours: Monday through Friday, 1 to 5 p.m.; or by appointment. 20 East Oakdene Avenue, Teaneck. (201) 836-8923.

RIVERRUN GALLERY ''Bonnie MacLean, Recent Paintings.'' Through Oct. 26. Opening reception: Saturday, 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. Hours: Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Mondays and Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. 5 p.m. 287 South Main Street (Route 29), Lambertville. (609) 397-3349.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - CAMDEN ''Every Picture Tells a Story,'' an exhibit that explores storytelling through narrative art. Through Nov. 11. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free. Stedman Gallery, Third Street between Cooper Street and Benjamin Franklin Bridge, Camden. (856) 225-6350.

TRENTON CITY MUSEUM ''Eleanor A. Magid: Improvisational Bridges.'' Through Nov. 5. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Sundays, 2 to 4 p.m. Ellarslie, Cadwalader Park, Trenton. (609) 989-3632.
WATCHUNG ARTS CENTER ''Live On Through Art.'' Through Oct. 27. Opening reception: today, 1 p.m. to 4 p.m. Hours: Monday through Saturday, 1 to 4 p.m. 18 Sterling Road, Watchung. (908) 753-0190.

WHEATON VILLAGE ''American Wheels Show.'' Today, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. ''American Glass: 1900-2000,'' featuring more than 100 industrial and decorative pieces. Through Oct. 22. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $6 for older people; $3.50 for students. No admission charge to the Gallery of American Craft. Exit 26, Route 55, Millville. (800) 998-4552, extension 2756.
FOR CHILDREN

APPEL FARM ARTS AND MUSIC CENTER ''The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,'' presented by Theaterworks USA. Saturday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $7 (advance); $9 (on the day). 457 Shirley Road, Elmer. (800) 394-1211.

EATONTOWN PLAYHOUSE The youth theater group presents: ''Laff-In School; Our Time at Tony's and Brotherhood of Immortals.'' Today at 12:30 p.m. Tickets: $7.50. 37 Highway 35 North, Tower Shopping Center, Eatontown. (732) 460-0100.

FORUM THEATER COMPANY ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow.'' Through Nov. 4. Performances are every Saturday at 11 a.m.; also this Thursday at 10 a.m. Tickets: $9. 314 Main Street, Metuchen. (732) 548-0582.
KELSEY THEATER ''Otherwise Known as Sheila the Great.'' Saturday at 2 p.m. and 4 p.m Tickets: $7. Mercer County Community College, 1200 Trenton Road, Trenton. (609) 921-9444.

MORRISTOWN UNITARIAN FELLOWSHIP ''Lyrica Visits the Zoo,'' music with harp, violin, cello, piano and stuffed animals. Saturday at 10 a.m. and 11:15 a.m. Tickets: $6 (advance); $8 (at the door). 21 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 701-1734.
STATE THEATER ''Franklin's Big Adventure.'' Next Sunday at 1 p.m. and 4 p.m. Tickets: $14. 15 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-7469.
STOCKTON PERFORMING ARTS CENTER ''Peter Pan.'' Thursday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $25 (orchestra); $20 (mezzanine). Richard Stockton College, Jim Leeds Road, Pomona. (609) 652-9000.

STONY BROOK-MILLSTONE WATERSHED ''Spooky Spiders'' for preschool children. Tuesday, 10 a.m. to 11:30 a.m.; Wednesday, 1 p.m. to 2:30 p.m. Fee: $8; $5 for members. ''Leaves Are Falling.'' Saturday at 10 a.m. Fee: $5; $3 for members. Pre-registration is required for all events. Buttinger Nature Center, 31 Titus Mill Road, Pennington. (609) 737-7592.
BARNES & NOBLE Tina Sinatra, daughter of Frank Sinatra, will sign copies of her memoir ''My Father's Daughter.'' Wednesday at 7 p.m. 59 Washington Street, Hoboken. (201) 653-1165.
SPOKEN WORD
BARNES & NOBLE Melanie George, author, will discuss and sign her book ''Like No Other.'' Thursday at 7:30 p.m. Free. 518 West Mount Pleasant Avenue, Livingston. (973) 535-9087.
BOOKENDS BOOKSTORE Liz Smith, columnist, will discuss and sign her book ''Natural Blonde: A Memoir.'' Tomorrow at 7 p.m. Free. 232 East Ridgewood Avenue, Ridgewood. (201) 445-0726.

BORDERS BOOKS AND MUSIC Constance O'Day-Flannery, author, will discuss and sign copies of her book ''Heaven on Earth.'' Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Michael Janke, author, will discuss and sign copies of his book ''Take Control: Master the Art of Self-Discipline and Change Your Life Forever.'' Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. Free. 515 Route 73 South, Unit 1, Marlton. (609) 985-5080.

RAMAPO COLLEGE David Sedaris, a regular contributor on National Public Radio, will read from his latest book ''Me Talk Pretty One Day.'' Friday at 11:30 a.m. Tickets: $15; $10 for older people; $5 for students. Sharp Theater, Berrie Center, 505 Ramapo Valley Road, Mahwah. (201) 684-7888.

RICHARD STOCKTON COLLEGE OF NEW JERSEY Sylvia Yount, chief curator of the Philadelphia Academy of the Fine Arts, will present a slide lecture titled ''From the Real to the Ideal: The Philadelphia Art World in the 1890's.'' Thursday at 3 p.m. Arts and Sciences lecture hall (AS102), Jim Leeds Road, Pomona. (609) 652-1776.
ETC.

47TH ANNUAL CHRYSANTHEMUM FLOWER SHOW Today, 10 a.m to 5 p.m. Free. Hundreds of prize-winning mums are on display; flower arrangements and potted garden mums for sale. Frelinghuysen Arboretum, Haggerty Education Building, 53 East Hanover Avenue, Morristown. (201) 326-7600.

AMERICAN INDIAN ARTS FESTIVAL Through tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. More than 150 artists and entertainers; 50 tribal nations represented. Admission: $10; $5 for older people and children under 12; free for children under 6. Rankokus Indian Reservation, Exit 45A from Interstate 295 or New Jersey Turnpike, Exit 5. Follow signs for Rancocas Road toward Mt. Holly. (609) 261-4747.

NEW JERSEY CONVENTION/EXPO CENTER ''Fall RV Show.'' Friday, 1 p.m. to 10 p.m.; Saturday, 11 a.m .to 10 p.m.; next Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Tickets: $7; $5 for children, 12 to 7 years of age; free for children under 12. 97 Sunfield Avenue, Edison. (800) 332-3976.631-0062.

NEW JERSEY FILM FESTIVAL FALL 2000 ''Paragraph 175.'' Today at 7 p.m. ''Beau Travail.'' Friday, Saturday and next Sunday at 7 p.m. Scott Hall, 123. Rutgers University, College Avenue and Hamilton Street, New Brunswick. ''Screen Tests.'' Tickets: $5; $4 for members.(732) 932-8482.

SIX FLAGS GREAT ADVENTURE ''9th Annual Fright Fest.'' Friday evenings, Saturdays and Sundays through Oct. 29. Includes Halloween-themed rides, attractions, shows and a ''Hallowedding'' ceremony on Friday. Free with admission, $43.96 (adult); $21.98 (child). Northern Star Arena, exit 7A off the New Jersey Turnpike. (732) 928-1821.

SOMERSET COUNTY PARK COMMISSION ''Fungus Fest 2000,'' New Jersey Mycological Association's annual mushroom fair. Next Sunday, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Suggested donation: $1.50; $.75 for children. Environmental Education Center, 190 Lord Stirling Road, Basking Ridge. (908) 766-2489.
AT THE CASINOS
All tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.
ATLANTIC CITY HILTON Paul Anka. Today at 8 p.m. Tickets: $45 and $50. Grand Theater, Boston and Pacific Avenues. (609) 340-7200.

BALLY'S PARK PLACE ''Legends in Concert.'' impersonations of Stevie Wonder, Little Richard, Elvis Presley, Linda Ronstadt and Barbra Streisand. Mondays through Thursdays at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 8 and 10:30 p.m.; Sundays at 7:30 and 10 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $25. Park Cabaret, Boardwalk and Park Place. (800) 225-5977.

CLARIDGE HOTEL The Duprees; Jack Fontana, comedian/impressionist (opening act). Today at 7 p.m. Tickets: $35. ''Jeff McBride's Abracadazzle.'' Through Nov. 16. Mondays through Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 8 p.m. and 11 p.m.; Sundays at 7 p.m. Tickets: $15, Sundays through Thursdays; $19, Saturdays. Palace Theater, Boardwalk and Park Place. (609) 340-3400.

SANDS HOTEL AND CASINO Sal Richards. Today at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20. ''A Shore Thing -- 3,'' presented by the Philadelphia Group Harmony Association and the United Group Harmony Association, starring the Florida Legends and Band. Friday at 10 p.m. Tickets: $30. ''The Embers.'' Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15. Indiana Avenue and Brighton Park. (609) 441-4137.

TROPICANA ''Tribute to Liberace,'' starring Daryl Wagner; the Lovely Liebowitz Sisters, guests. Through Dec. 3; call for show times. Tickets: $15. ''Dresses of Diana, Princess of Wales Exhibit.'' Through Dec. 28. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. Tickets: $13.95; $11.95 for older people; $6.95 for children, aged 5 to 11. Boardwalk and Brighton Avenue. (609) 340-3020.
